conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light; their shape and size depend on the object's shape, light source position, and distance to the surface.
The light source is initially positioned above the objects, casting shadows A, B, C, and D on the ground.
When the light source moves downward, it gets closer to the objects, affecting both the position and size of the shadows.
As the light source moves downward, the angle of the light rays changes, causing shadows to shift closer to the objects and move upward on the ground.
The size of the shadows is inversely proportional to the distance between the light source and the objects, so shadows become smaller as the light source moves downward.
The shadows A, B, C, and D will move closer to the objects and become smaller in size if the light source moves downward.
